title: 107_hr1387
content: The Drug Availability and Health Care Access Improvement Act of 2001 includes provisions for Medicaid prescription drug coverage for low-income Medicare beneficiaries, improved access to Medicare+Choice plans, and enhanced access to reasonably priced prescription drugs. Amendments to program for importation of certain prescription drugs by pharmacists and wholesalers. Medicaid prescription drug coverage for low-income Medicare beneficiaries. Amendment to the Social Security Act to provide medical assistance for prescribed drugs to qualified Medicare beneficiaries and individuals with income slightly above the poverty line. Amendment to the Social Security Act allows for 100 percent federal financing of additional costs for medical assistance for prescribed drugs. Sliding scale premiums are permitted for qualifying individuals with incomes above 135 percent of the poverty line. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows for 100% federal financing of additional costs for medical assistance for prescribed drugs. For individuals with incomes above 135% of the poverty line, a sliding scale premium is implemented, ranging from 0% to 100% as income increases from 135% to 175% of the poverty line. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows for 100% federal financing of additional costs for medical assistance for prescribed drugs. For individuals with incomes above 135% of the poverty line, a sliding scale premium is implemented, ranging from 0% to 100% as income increases from 135% to 175% of the poverty line. States cannot require prepayment of the premium or terminate eligibility for failure to pay for at least 60 days. States may waive the premium in cases of undue hardship and use other funds for payment without counting it as income. The amendments take effect more than 6 months after the enactment of the Act. Improved access to Medicare+Choice plans through an increase in the minimum Medicare+Choice capitation rate. The minimum Medicare+Choice capitation rate is increased for 2002, with a set amount for areas in the 50 states and the District of Columbia, and a minimum amount for other areas based on the previous year's rate and national growth percentage. The Medicare+Choice capitation rate is increased for 2002, with adjustments made to certain clauses for 2003. The amendments apply to years starting from 2002. Title III focuses on improving access to reasonably priced prescription drugs through amendments to the program for importation of certain prescription drugs by pharmacists and wholesalers. Section 804 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to require testing of imported products by the importer or manufacturer, with necessary authentication information provided. The amendment to Section 804 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act requires imported products to be tested by the importer or manufacturer, with protection for confidential information provided. Importers can use approved labeling for products under section 505, and the Secretary has discretion to waive testing requirements under certain conditions. The amendment to Section 804 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act prohibits manufacturers from entering agreements that prevent the sale of imported products and prohibits discrimination against US pharmacists, wholesalers, or consumers. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on permitted imports. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on permitted imports under the amendment to Section 804 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The study will evaluate importers' compliance with regulations and consult with relevant authorities to assess the impact on trade and patent rights. A report must be submitted within 5 years of final regulations being issued. The Comptroller General will prepare a report for Congress on the study regarding discrimination in access to covered products by pharmacists, wholesalers, or consumers. Subsection (k)(2) is amended to include provisions on discrimination in contracts or supply limitations. The amendment includes changes to subsections (k)(2) and (m), authorizing appropriations for fiscal years 2002 and beyond to carry out the section.
